name: Student Technology Protection Act
description: Requires instructor and student education on safe use of technology;  tightens acceptable usage and filtering policies at schools.
reasoning: This bill focuses on educational requirements for technology safety instruction, cybersecurity through filtering and usage policies, and broader online safety measures in school settings. The governance approach involves requiring institutional policy changes rather than direct platform regulation.

name: PROTECTION OF MINORS – Adds to existing law to establish the Parental Rights Protection of Minors Act to protect minors from exposure to harmful materials on certain devices.
description: Requires tablet/smartphone manufacturers to have filters that are enabled at activation and only bypassed or switched off with password. Crime for non-parents to deactivate filter and allow minors to access harmful content.
reasoning: This bill primarily focuses on content filtering requirements for device manufacturers, establishing design standards for mandatory filters, and creating criminal liability for bypassing these protections - distinguishing it from general online safety bills through its device-level approach and specific liability framework.

name: PROTECTION OF MINORS – Adds to existing law to establish the Parental Rights Protection of Minors Act to protect minors from exposure to harmful materials on certain devices.
description: Requires tablet/smartphone manufacturers to have filters that are enabled at activation and only bypassed or switched off with password. Crime for non-parents to deactivate filter and allow minors to access harmful content.
reasoning: This bill primarily focuses on content filtering requirements for device manufacturers, establishing design standards for mandatory filters, and creating criminal liability for bypassing these protections - distinguishing it from general online safety bills through its device-level approach and specific liability framework.

name: Creates the Children's Privacy Protection and Parental Empowerment Act
description: Requires online services likely to be used by children to conduct impact assessments and mitigation plans for harm to children;  estimate age of users;  default privacy settings to most protective for child users. Use of user data for children highly restricted. Establishes working group to develop best practices.
reasoning: Privacy is primary due to data use restrictions and default protective settings. Online safety captures the harm mitigation focus. Design and testing standards reflects the impact assessments and mitigation plans requirements. Governance remains Platforms + Democracy as it mandates platform design changes and impact assessments.

name: Creates the Minor Online Data Privacy Act.

name: Internet safety curricula for schools
description: Permits schools to teach Internet safety and instructs state education department to create curricular materials  at, minimally, elementary and high school levels.

'Online safety' and 'Cybersecurity' capture the specific safety focus. name: An Act relating to civil liability for commercial entities who publish or distribute material harmful to minors on the internet and providing penalties.
description: Requires age verification to access websites that are more than one-third pornography. Retaining ID information prohibited.
reasoning: Primary focus is online safety through age verification requirements, creates civil liability framework for non-compliant entities, and includes privacy protections by prohibiting ID information retention

name: An Act relating to social media users under eighteen years of age, making penalties applicable, and including applicability provisions.
description: Prohibits social media platforms from allowing under 18s having accounts.

The authorization/licensing tag applies as it restricts who can access platform services based on age requirements. The governance remains Platforms + Democracy as it mandates platform operational changes.

reasoning: Bill specifically targets data collection practices regarding minors, making Privacy the primary focus. Online safety is secondary as the bill aims to protect children through data restrictions. Governance remains Privacy/Data Rights as it restricts platform data collection from minors.

name: Removing liability protections from online platforms and requiring certain wireless communication devices to have a default setting notifying parents of application downloads.

name: Age Verification to Protect Children Act.
description: Requires age verification to access websites that are more than one-third pornography.
reasoning: Bill focuses on online safety through age verification requirements for pornographic websites, which directly involves content moderation and free speech considerations around access restrictions

name: Social Media Algorithmic Control in IT Act.
description: Prohibits social media platforms using minor users' data for recommendation algorithms and targeted advertising. Establishes task force to report on data privacy and social media [precise remit unclear].
reasoning: Bill specifically targets algorithmic recommendation systems using minor data, restricts data collection/use practices, and establishes reporting mechanisms for transparency. Primary focus is data rights protection rather than content moderation.

name: Let Parents Choose/Sammy's Law of 2023
description: Requires social media platforms to make APIs available to facilitate the development and use of third-party safety software to control / monitor platform settings and interactions. Platforms must obtain and renew state permits.
reasoning: The bill requires state permits for platforms (licensing), mandates API availability for third-party safety software (platform design changes), and creates operational requirements beyond basic content moderation - focusing on structural platform obligations rather than content regulation.

name: [R]elating to the definition of a public library and required safety policies and technology protection measures;  ... relating to obscenity control;  to provide a penalty;  and to provide for application.
description: Requires online content vendors to schools (and libraries when making content available to school-age children) to use filters.
reasoning: This bill primarily focuses on content filtering requirements for online vendors serving schools and libraries, making it fundamentally about content moderation. Education and research captures the school/library context, while public procurement reflects the vendor relationship requirements.

name: Regards education records and student data privacy
description: Strictly limits school tech vendors' use of student data;  prohibits schools and vendors tracking or recording students via devices.
reasoning: Bill primarily focuses on student data privacy by restricting how school tech vendors can use student data and prohibiting tracking/recording via devices. Education tag captures the school context that distinguishes this from general child privacy bills.

name: Human trafficking and child exploitation;  creating the Human Trafficking and Child Exploitation Prevention Act;  directing retailers of Internet-enabled devices to equip products with certain filters;  codification;  effective date.
description: Requires device retailers / manufacturers to have filters that are enabled at activation and only disabled by adults paying a fee.
reasoning: This bill mandates content filtering on internet-enabled devices with paid opt-out, directly regulating content moderation mechanisms. It creates liability requirements for retailers/manufacturers and focuses on online safety through mandatory filtering systems.

name: Relating to business's use of age-appropriate design
description: Requires online services likely to be used by children to prioritize the well-being of children over commercial interests;  conduct impact assessments and mitigation plans for harm to children;  default privacy settings to most protective for child users;  enforce their own policies. Use of user data for children highly restricted. Establishes task force to report on best practices.
reasoning: This bill primarily focuses on privacy protections through data use restrictions, mandates design standards like default protective settings and impact assessments, and addresses broader online safety. The governance approach requires platform design changes and impact assessments rather than content moderation or pure data restrictions.

name: An Act providing for protection of certain personal data of consumers;  imposing duties on controllers and processors of personal data of consumers;  providing for enforcement;  prescribing penalties;  and establishing the Consumer Privacy Fund.
description: General data privacy bill that categorizes all personal data relating to minors as "sensitive."
reasoning: This is a general data privacy bill that specifically categorizes minor data as sensitive, focusing on data protection rights and controller/processor duties rather than content moderation or platform design changes.

name: An Act amending Title 18 (Crimes and Offenses) of the Pennsylvania Consolidated Statutes, making editorial changes to replace references to the term "child pornography" with references to the term "child sexual abuse material."
description: Replaces references "child pornography" with "child sexual abuse material" in existing law.
reasoning: This bill focuses on updating terminology around child sexual abuse material in existing criminal law, which directly relates to online safety enforcement and content regulation. The change from 'child pornography' to 'child sexual abuse material' reflects modern approaches to content moderation and legal frameworks addressing harmful content.

name: An Act amending the act of November 30, 2004 (P.L.1556, No.197), known as the Child Internet Protection Act, further providing for title and for definitions;  and making editorial changes.
description: Replaces references "child pornography" with "child sexual abuse material" in existing law.
reasoning: This bill updates terminology in existing child internet protection law by replacing 'child pornography' with 'child sexual abuse material', which is primarily a content classification and moderation issue affecting how harmful content is defined and regulated.

name: AN ACT RELATING TO EDUCATION -- STUDENT COMPUTER DEVICE PRIVACY
description: Prohibits schools and vendors tracking or recording students via devices in most cases.
reasoning: Bill specifically prohibits tracking/recording students via school devices, making Privacy the primary focus. Education and research captures the school context. Governance is Privacy/Data Rights as it restricts data collection practices regarding minors in educational settings.

name: AN ACT RELATING TO COMMERCIAL LAW -- GENERAL REGULATORY PROVISIONS -- RHODE ISLAND DATA TRANSPARENCY AND PRIVACY PROTECTION ACT (Provides data privacy protections for the personal identifiable information of Rhode Islanders.)
description: General data privacy bill that categorizes all personal data relating to children as "sensitive";  prohibits processing or selling personal data of minor customers.
reasoning: This is primarily a general data privacy bill that treats children's data as sensitive and prohibits processing/selling minor data. The transparency aspect comes from the bill's name referencing 'Data Transparency.' The governance clearly falls under Privacy/Data Rights as it restricts data collection and use from minors.

name: AN ACT RELATING TO COMMERCIAL LAW -- GENERAL REGULATORY PROVISIONS -- RHODE ISLAND DATA TRANSPARENCY AND PRIVACY PROTECTION ACT (Provides data privacy protections for the personal identifiable information of Rhode Islanders.
description: General data privacy bill that categorizes all personal data relating to children as "sensitive";  prohibits processing or selling personal data of minor customers.
reasoning: This is primarily a comprehensive data privacy bill that treats children's data as sensitive and restricts processing/selling of minors' personal data. The transparency aspect comes from the bill's name indicating data transparency protections. The governance approach focuses on restricting data collection and use from minors.

name: Child Online Safety Act
description: Requires age verification to access websites or apps that are principally pornography. Retaining ID information prohibited.
reasoning: Bill requires age verification for pornography sites (online safety/content moderation), involves ID collection and retention restrictions (privacy), and regulates access to adult content (content moderation). Primary governance approach is content moderation through age verification requirements.

name: Child Online Safety Act
description: Requires age verification to access websites or apps that are principally pornography.
reasoning: Bill specifically requires age verification for pornography websites/apps, which is a content moderation approach to online safety rather than broader platform regulation or privacy-focused measures

name: A BILL TO AMEND THE SOUTH CAROLINA CODE OF LAWS BY ADDING SECTION 63-5-380 SO AS TO PROHIBIT THE COLLECTION OF PERSONAL INFORMATION FROM CHILDREN BY OPERATORS OF WEBSITES, ONLINE SERVICES, AND ONLINE OR MOBILE APPLICATIONS AND TO ESTABLISH PENALTIES.
description: Prohibits online services from collecting personal information of minors.
reasoning: Bill specifically prohibits collection of personal information from children by online operators, making privacy the primary focus. Online safety is secondary as it's the broader protective goal. Governance is clearly Privacy/Data Rights as it restricts data collection practices.

name: Social media regulation
description: Prohibits online services using an "automated decision system for content placement" for minors. Requires age verification to use them.
reasoning: Bill specifically targets automated decision systems for content placement (algorithms), requires age verification systems (authorization/licensing), and mandates platform design changes to protect minors online, fitting the platforms + democracy governance model.

name: Children's Default to Safety Act
description: Requires tablet/smartphone manufacturers to have filters that are enabled at activation and only bypassed or switched off with password. Crime for non-parents to deactivate filter and allow minors to access harmful content.
reasoning: This bill primarily focuses on content filtering requirements (content moderation), mandates specific device design standards for manufacturers, and creates criminal liability for non-parents who bypass filters - distinguishing it from other child safety bills through its hardware-focused approach and criminal penalties.

name: An Act to provide liability for the publishing or distributing of material harmful to minors on the internet and the wrongful retention of individually identifiable information.
description: Requires age verification to access websites that are more than one-third pornography. Retaining ID information prohibited.

name: Relating to requirements for the use and transfer of electronic devices to students by a public school.
description: Requires the adoption of policies for student-held school-owned devices that limit data collection, require parental consent for software, curfew, possibly limit access to social media and report harm-related content to schools and parents. Devices must have pornography filters and schools to educate parents about Internet safety.
reasoning: Primary focus on data collection limitations and parental consent (Privacy), pornography filters and harm reporting (Online safety), and parent education requirements (Education and research). Privacy/Data Rights governance fits the bill's emphasis on restricting data collection from student devices and requiring parental consent.

name: Social Media Usage Amendments
description: Prohibits social media platforms from using design that is addictive to minors;  exempts those that conduct quarterly assessments and mitigations. Creates a civil cause of action against platforms for any harm caused to minors from using the platform.
reasoning: This bill specifically targets addictive design features and algorithmic manipulation (Design and testing standards, Algorithms), creates civil liability for platforms (Liability), and requires quarterly assessments and platform design changes (Platforms + Democracy governance approach).

name: Social Media Regulation Amendments
description: Requires age verification to open social media accounts without parental consent (retaining ID information prohibited). For minor accounts: messaging and discoverability limited, advertising, suggestions, and most data collection prohibited;  curfew enabled. Parents to receive access to posts by minor and ability to set time limits.
reasoning: This bill primarily focuses on privacy through data collection restrictions and parental access controls, online safety through messaging/discoverability limits and curfews, and authorization through age verification requirements. The governance approach centers on restricting data collection/use from minors rather than content moderation.

name: An act relating to funding for the Vermont Internet Crimes Against Children (VT-ICAC) Task Force
description: Appropriates funds for the Vermont Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force and creates three staff positions.
reasoning: This bill appropriates funds and creates government positions for a task force focused on internet crimes against children, making it primarily about cybersecurity enforcement and government funding/staffing rather than regulating platforms or content directly.

name: Consumer Data Protection Act;  protections for children, definition of verifiable parental consent
description: Requires parental consent for minor accounts with services that process data, or to collect and use minors' data;  prohibits sale of minors' personal data, or using it for targeted advertising. Raises age of majority in existing data protection law to 18.
reasoning: Primary focus is on data privacy protections for minors including parental consent requirements, prohibition on data sales, and restrictions on targeted advertising. Online safety is secondary as these privacy measures serve broader child protection goals.
